p: Figure 2 shows the inhibitory effect of ethanolic and aqueous extracts from E. cyparissias on the three digestive phospholipases used. Interestingly, the obtained data clearly indicated that both the ethanolic and the aqueous extracts (Figures 2(a) and 2(b)) effectively suppressed activities of all phospholipases used better than the oleanolic acid used as a positive control ( Figure 2(c)). The IC 50 values presented in Table 2 showed that the ethanolic extract was about two to three times more efficient to inhibit the digestive phospholipases used than the aqueous extract. The ethanolic extract inhibited the three enzymes with an IC 50 of 4.2 ± 0.2 μg/mL for DrPLA 2-IB, 5.9 ± 0.2 μg/mL for SPLA 2-IB, and 9.6 ± 0.2 μg/mL for PPLA 2-IB.
